section.title: Objective and Overview
section.para: The objective of this tutorial is to learn how to create a spacecraft and a propagator, and then propagate the spacecraft to the desired position - in this example, to the orbit periapsis. The meaning of the term "propagate" here is simulating the spacecraft travel from its initial position until some given condition is met - for example, a predefined location or elapsed time. (See the GMAT Help module for more detail.) We perform this simulation by following the basic steps below. (Here and elsewhere, unless specified further, "click" will mean "left-click" of your computer cursor):

listitem.para: Configure the resources - create a spacecraft and define its epoch and orbital elements.
Create and configure a propagator.
Modify the default Orbit View to visualize the spacecraft trajectory.
Configure the mission sequence to propagate the spacecraft to the periapsis.
Finally, run the mission.

section.title: Creating and Configuring a Spacecraft
section.para: In this section we will set the spacecraft's initial epoch and classical orbital elements. You will need GMAT open, with the default mission loaded. The default mission is loaded when a new session of the GMAT executable is started or when the New Mission button in the Toolbar is clicked.

section.title: Creating a Spacecraft
section.para: Working from the GUI, you can create a new spacecraft by starting at the Resource Tree.

listitem.para: Rename the default spacecraft DefaultSC, by right-clicking it and selecting Rename from the drop-down menu. For this tutorial, name the spacecraft Sat.
Double left-click your Sat spacecraft - this opens open the Spacecraft dialog box. If it is not already selected, click on the Orbit Tab.
Left-click the Epoch Format drop-down menu and select UTCGregorian. You'll see the value in the Epoch field change to the UTC Gregorian epoch format.
Left-click in the Epoch field, and type the desired value of 22 Jul 2014 11:29:10.811 (or you can cut and paste from this text).
Save the changes by clicking the Apply button at the bottom of the dialog box window.

section.title: Setting a Spacecraft's State
section.para: In this tutorial we will use the Keplerian orbital elements, and we will enter them with respect to Earth's MJ2000 Equator system.

listitem.para: Continuing with the Spacecraft dialog box: change the state type to Keplerian by clicking the State Type drop-down menu and selecting "Keplerian". In Elements on the right you will see the GUI reconfiguring to the Keplerian representation.

section.title: Creating and Configuring the Propagator
section.para: Creating a new propagator involves selecting a numerical integrator and a force model. Let's start with the propagator:

listitem.para: Locate the Propagators folder in the Resource Tree.
We will use the default propagator DefaultProp. (Or, you can right-click the Propagators folder and select Add Propagator from the drop-down menu.)
Rename DefaultProp to LowEarthProp. (For this, right-click the DefaultProp, select Rename, type in the new name In the dialog box, and click OK.)
Double left-click LowEarthProp to open its dialog box called PropSet. On the left side of the box you find the Integrator settings; we will use the default values. model.

section.title: Configuring the Force Model
section.para: For this tutorial we will use an Earth 10x10 non-spherical gravity model, Jacchia-Roberts atmospheric model, and point mass perturbations from the Sun and Moon.

listitem.para: We continue with the PropSet-LowEarthProp dialog box. We will now configurets right side, which contains information on the force model.
Locate the Primary Bodies group on the Force Model box. In the Gravity group box, change both the Degree and Order to 10 by typing in these values.
In the Drag group of Force Model, click the Atmosphere Model pull-down menu and select the JacchiaRoberts model.
Click the Select button to the right of the Point Masses text box. This opens a box with a list of gravitational bodies from which we can select our Primary Bodies.
Select "Sun" in the Available Bodies list, and add it to Selected Bodies on the right by clicking the right arrow found between the two columns.
Add similarly the Moon (named Luna in GMAT) to Selected Bodies. The Select Bodies box should now look as the one shown below.
Click OK to save the selected bodies and close the box.

section.para: Back in the PropSetup dialog box, make sure the box Use Solar Radiation Pressure is checked. You dialog box should now look as shown below. Click OK to save and close it..

section.title: Configuring the Orbit View Plot
section.para: Here we will configure the default Orbit View plot that will show our spacecraft Sat. We will also configure the view point, to allow us to see the entire orbit as we propagate the spacecraft.

listitem.para: In the Output folder in Resource Tree, double-left-click the DefaultOrbitView to open the OrbitView dialog box.
In the View Object group, make sure that our spacecraft Sat is the only item in the Selected Spacecraft list. (If needed, use the procedure we used above to form the Selected Bodies list.)

The orbit of Sat is highly eccentric. To view the entire orbit in the plot, we need to adjust the settings in the View Definition group. Namely, set the pull-down menu of the View Point Vector to Vector, and set its three numerical settings to 30000, -5000, and 5000 respectively.
Uncheck the DrawXY Plane box in the Drawing Option group.
Your OrbitView dialog box should now look as shown in the figure below. Click OK to save and close it.

section.title: Creating a Propagate Command
section.para: The last step in this tutorial will be to propagate the spacecraft along its orbit. To this end, we need to configure a propagate command so that it will propagate until the spacecraft reaches the orbit periapis.

listitem.para: Click the Mission tab to bring up the mission sequence. (The tab appears next to the Resources tab, near the upper left-hand corner of the GMAT GUI.)
Double left click on the event named Propagate1. This opens the Propagate dialog box.

Make sure that the the field under the Propagator column contains LowEarthProp. (If not, right-click the first line of that column, and in the little Propagator box that opens, click LowEarthProp. Your little box should look as shown below. Hit OK.)

Back in the Propagate1 dialog box, make sure that the Spacecraft List on the right contains our spacecraft Sat. (If not, right-click the list's top line, and select Sat in the list box that opens; hit OK.)

figure.title: Propagate Command Space Object Select Dialog

section.title: Selecting a Stopping Condition
section.para: The only remaining thing now is to tell the propagator when to stop the propagation.

listitem.para: In the Stopping Conditions group of our Propagate1 dialog box, right click the field in the Parameter column (it may now contain something - e.g. Sat.ElapsedSecs.)
In the ParameterSelectDialog box that opens, select Sat in the Object List on the left. (This directs GMAT to associate the stopping condition with the spacecraft named Sat.)
Locate the Object Properties list in the middle of the box, scroll down and select Periapsis.

Click the right-pointing arrow between the Object Properties and Selected Value(s) columns. This forms a variable Sat.Earth.Periapsis and places it in the Selected Value(s) column on the right. (See the figure below.) Click OK to save your changes.

section.title: Running the Mission
section.para: With the mission now fully configured, it is time to run it and see the results.

listitem.para: Click the Save button in the toolbar to save your mission script.
Click the Run button in the toolbar.

section.para: You should see GMAT propagate the orbit and stop at orbit periapsis. The screen capture below summarizes what you should see after correctly completing this tutorial. You can manipulate the Orbit View plot using your mouse to zoom in/out and rotate the plot.
